texts.shortText:
Chironomid midges resemble small mosquitoes and have a humped thorax, long slender front legs and relatively short wings that are normally held folded along the back when at rest. Males can be distinguished by having conspicuous tufts of hairs encircling their antennae.

Members of the genus Telmatogeton are best identified by their unusual habitat on the upper reaches of rocky shores and their association with seaweeds as a larval food source. There are two very similar species in the region that are difficult to distinguish without microscopic examination. Larvae are greenishâ€“brown and have a dark head capsule.
Adults about 4 mm body/ length excluding antennae. Larvae up to 10 mm.

Global: T. sancti-pauli is known form various islands in the Atlantic Ocean and from South Africa. T. minor is endemic.

Local/Regional: Both from about Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.

Females can be seen at low tide fluttering among seaweeds, where they lay their eggs. Larvae live and feed amongst the folded fronds of algae, especially Porphyra but probably also Ulva on which they are often seen. Larvae may be an important component in the diets of intertidal fishes.
Larvae feed on marine algae, particularly species of Porphyra. Many chironomids do not feed as adults and that is probably the case with these species as well.
Eggs are laid on intertidal algae and the larvae feed on these. Pupation also takes place amongst the algal fronds.

There are over 175 chironomid species in South Africa, but members of this genus are the only ones in the Western Cape region to be associated with marine algae and hence unlikely to be confused with other members of the group. There is one other marine chironomid known from South Africa  (Clunio africanus Hesse, 1937) but this has only reported from KwaZulu-Natal.
